[{'id': 371, 'article_title': 'Anamaboe', 'full_section_title': 'Anamaboe', 'last_edit_date': '03-24-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1864#article-9', 'issue_date': '23_06_1864', 'content': "The second anniversary of the Anamaboe Temperance Society has been held at this place, the principal scene of its operations. The meeting was on the 24th of March, 1864, at the Wesleyan chapel, S. C. Brew, Esq., J.P., in the chair, in company with the President and Vice-President and two other friends of the movement. His worship made an excellent address, very favourable to the cause, the substance of which will appear in the society's report for the past year."}, {'id': 1086, 'article_title': 'WESLEYAN MISSIONARY MEETING AT CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'WESLEYAN MISSIONARY MEETING AT CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '02-11-1867', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1867#article-23', 'issue_date': '23_04_1867', 'content': "The yearly meeting of this highly successful mission society was held at Cape Coast on Monday, the 11th February, his Excellency H. J. Usher, Acting Administrator, in the chair.

Amongst the gentlemen on the platform were the Rev. Mr. Blake (Colonial Chaplain), Major Mends, Lieuts. Sayce and Hamilton, of the 2nd West India Regiment; T. B. Freeman, Esq., F. C. Grant, Esqs.; Revs. Messrs. West, Wharton, Soloman, Fynn, and a host of other Wesleyan ministers.

The proceedings opened with prayer by Mr. West, after which his Excellency the Acting Administrator addressed the meeting, showing the great good that has resulted from the efforts of Wesleyans, and in a most impressive manner contrasted the days of human sacrifice and bloodshed on the Gold Coast with the comparative happiness that prevails now, and which he traced directly to the efforts of the Wesleyan Society. His Excellency, after passing some well-deserved encomiums on the Revs. Mr. West, Mr. Wharton, and the other Wesleyan ministers, concluded by soliciting the aid of all present, alluding in a most touching and beautiful manner to the parable of the widow's mite. The Rev. Mr. West then read the report for the last year, which showed results far exceeding those of the previous one, both as regards success in the work and in a pecuniary point of view, and proved that the admirers and supporters of this excellent society have not degenerated. The amount collected for the Gold Coast district exceeded the sum of 800l., being an increase of 200l. over last year.

His Excellency, after the report was read, rose and complimented Mr. West on the success of this year's labour, and called upon the Rev. Mr. Taylor to address the meeting, which he did in a most amusing speech, which created loud bursts of applause and laughter. His Excellency then called upon T. B. Freeman, Esq., to address the meeting. At this announcement the utmost silence prevailed, as it was well known that one of the greatest orators that ever graced an African platform was about to give utterance to words that would charm and delight the audience. Mr. Freeman rose, and whilst doing so a breathless silence pervaded the vast assembly."}, {'id': 3005, 'article_title': 'The Primitive Methodist School at Fernando Po', 'full_section_title': 'The Primitive Methodist School at Fernando Po', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1875#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_12_1875', 'content': 'Sir,—In your June paper I found that some one has tried to prove my assertions false; as regards the principal people sending for the Church of England and obscure individuals for the Primitive Methodist, this I do not care for. Rather than feeling disappointed, as the person who wrote as "One of the People" had wished, I am glad, because his letter acts as a provocative all over our colony, and is helping greatly towards eliciting hidden truth. So I will make no attempt to prove its falsity, for it is helping the cause I am aiming at. As regards the Schoolmaster's article, it bears its own weakness in every line. He calls the Primitive Methodist Society "our Society." So do I; they are "our Society." We love them for their labour of love and work of patience; and for this reason we appeal to them to fulfil the design of their mission in this island, which I think is Christianity and civilization; and let no ignorant black man blind their eyes with his self-interest. Another thing, Mr. Editor, I must say: we are still hoping, longing, wishing, that our grievance may be redressed, but for the present things are still in their downward movement; and to add to the calamity, the parents being impatient, have taken out from the schools all the grown-up boys and girls, because of the ignorance of the schoolmaster and the indifference of the minister. Our beautiful roses are all nipped in the bud. What can we do, Mr. Editor, but appeal to the Director of the Society? If one man could carry nineteen pounds weight, and another one pound, and these two persons be set to carry twenty pounds weight, will this enable the one-pound-weight man to carry twenty another time? No. I do not think any one can reason so weakly; and yet this is what the schoolmaster did. He said that the two years alluded to by me in the March paper were worked by him and Mr. Savage, his colleague. This no one denies; but what I say is that Mr. Savage did nine-tenths of the work, and the rest our friend Mr. Crooke did. But now the load has crushed him down; and if he had been sincere, he would have been glad to see some one who is calling out a relief for him. But instead of this, he is acting from self-interest, to the molestation of the public. As there is no other medium that would assist oppressed Africans, we appeal to you, Mr. Editor, to send one of your papers to the Primitive Methodist Society, with the article of "Progress" and that of the Schoolmaster. Meanwhile allow me to sign my name again,

**Progress.**

P.S.—To assure you that I intend nothing but good for my country, I do nothing to injure any one, but for good for the growing up ones. As a truthful man, I again give you my name in full, but I do not wish it to be published.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'Interesting Annual Wesleyan Missionary Meeting, Accra, Gold Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"This meeting is of opinion that as education in the English language—now the great business language of the world—is highly popular among our native people generally in all the Coast towns, there would be no difficulty, on that score, of raising the average daily attendance of scholars from ninety to three or four hundred."

After reading this resolution, Mr. Ribeiro interpreted it in the native language, making, as he proceeded, sundry apposite remarks and explanations, and closed his address by declaring that the great desideratum for the elevation of social life in Accra is a state of society based on Christian principles.

The resolution was seconded by Mr. Robert Bruce, and supported by Mr. James Bannerman, with very appropriate remarks thereupon, and was then put to the vote and carried with acclamation.

Mr. Wharton, on the resolution being handed to him by the Chairman, with the earnest request of the meeting that he would bring it under the notice of the Committee, answered that its substance vibrated on every chord of his heart, and he would do all he could in its advocacy.

Mr. Freeman (the last speaker) then remarked (it was now 10 P.M.) that the strikingly practical addresses of the Chairman and other gentlemen, and Mr. Fritz's warm pastoral, had left nothing further to be said, and called attention at once to the collection. It was said in the Book of Revelation, "The earth helped the woman." The woman there mentioned is the Church of Christ. It behoved the audience, the sons and daughters of earth, to help the Church on earth with all the gold and silver they could throw into its treasury, to aid in the extension of the Gospel, and look for remuneration in the gracious promise, "The Lord shall guide thee continually, and satisfy thy soul in drought, and make fat thy bones; and thou shalt be like a watered garden, and like a spring of water whose waters fail not."

The collection was then made, and amounted, including subscriptions from the out-stations of the circuit, to 106l.

The usual votes of thanks were then passed, and the meeting, a deeply interesting one, was closed with the Doxology and Benediction.—I am, dear Sir, yours, &c.,', 'last_edit_date': '1872-03-07', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1872#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'WESLEYAN MISSIONARY MEETING AT CAPE COAST.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Freeman said: It is now twenty-eight years since I had the high honour of addressing audiences such as these, and on this very spot, and when I contemplate the past, and reflect on the associations that have wedded my heart and soul to this great and good society, I find that words are inadequate to express my gratification. The Rev. Mr. Taylor has told you that the Wesleyans on the Coast of Africa are still to be compared to an overgrown child, whose period of life induces its parent to expect that it should walk, and so relieve its mother of the trouble of carrying it. I must, however, join issue with my friend Mr. Taylor, and, in doing so, ask him to take himself back to the year 1839, and contrast the present state of society with those dark and dismal times of human sacrifice and misery which owed their origin to the fact that God was not known to the heathen nor were his precepts followed by them. Now what do we see? Why, through the length and breadth of this vast protectorate chapels and missionary stations are being planted, and I bless God that I have had the honoured privilege of raising up many of those temples, and of dedicating them to that God who is alone able to accomplish the great work of spreading the religion of his dear Son. When I saw the misery and woe that prevailed in my travels through this benighted country, when I was forced to look upon the bloodstained streets of the Ashantee and Dahomey capitals, bleeding heads and mutilated bodies, rendered so to satisfy a restless Fetish, and a most depraved and senseless religion, it was then that I felt keenly the responsibility of missionary labour; it was then that I, with more earnestness than I ever before possessed, fell down at the footstool of my God and prayed for the success of missions in Western Africa. It was then that I realized fully the necessity, the urgent necessity, of planting here the religion of Jesus Christ; because I found out that no medicine, no physician, but He who died for us, and rose again for our justification, could heal so great a malady. Depend upon it, my friends, if you wish to elevate this unfortunate country, if you wish to pull down superstition, paganism, and idolatry, this, this is your only way, by supporting this noble society in raising up the cross of Christ and Him crucified—by earnestness in your prayers, and unflinching exertion in every effort, so that your goodness be not as the morning cloud or the early dew which goeth away. Rather let it give place to that happy state of belief: "For as the rain cometh down and the snow from heaven, and returneth not thither, but watereth the earth, and maketh it bring forth and bud, that it may give seed to the sower and bread to the eater; so shall my word be, that goeth forth out of my mouth; it shall not return unto me void, but it shall accomplish that which I please, and it shall prosper in the thing whereto I sent it. For ye shall go out with joy, and be led forth with peace. The mountains and the hills shall break forth before you into singing, and all the trees of the field shall clap their hands. Instead of the thorn shall come up the fir-tree, and instead of the brier shall come up the myrtle-tree; and it shall be to the Lord for a name, for an everlasting sign, that shall not be cut off." Hasten, oh Lord, the time when there shall be a new heaven and a new earth, and permit us to realize that beautiful portion of our prayer, "Thy kingdom come."', 'last_edit_date': '1867-02-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1867#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.738, 'probability_score': 0.071, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Missionary Progress in the Eastern Districts of the Gold Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The annual meetings of both the Wesleyan and the Basle Missionary Societies have been held at Accra. At the former, held on the 28th December, Captain Edmunds, 4th West India Regiment, presided. There had been an increase of 22 members during the past year. Several of the Basle missionaries spoke at this meeting.

At the Basle meeting, held on the 6th January, the report showed an increase during the year of 167. The mission has now 959 members. In the school there are 494 attendants. The staff consists of missionaries, 30; wives of ditto, 17; catechists, 29.

A mercantile establishment is connected with this mission. There is also an industrial department, with workshops for carpenters, joiners, smiths, wheelwrights, locksmiths, &c.

The Basle mission on the Gold Coast is in a very efficient state, and is doing immense good in the districts where it labours. Uniting the teaching and practice of agriculture and other useful industries with religious teaching, its sphere of usefulness becomes necessarily more extended than that of any exclusively religious mission could possibly be.

* I might mention that there were always hostilities between the Aquamoos and the Krepees until Mr. Freeman went up and settled their disputes, in 1859; and since his suspension from office they have ventured more strongly than ever upon their former quarrels.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-02-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1864#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.656, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SOUTH AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Wesleyan Missionary Society continues to receive most gratifying intelligence of the advance of Christianity among the natives of South Africa. The great work of conversion is progressing among the Kafirs, though polygamy is found here, as in other parts where it prevails, a most formidable barrier against the acceptance of the Gospel of Jesus Christ. More than 5,000 converts have been registered in the Cape Colony and in Kaffraria (exclusive of Natal) by the Wesleyan missionaries there during six months.', 'last_edit_date': '1867-07-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1867#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.698, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "Why the Wesleyan Missionary Society in Freetown Dispensed with the Great Number of Youths Trained up at King Tom's Point", 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—It is an undoubted fact that the Wesleyan Missionary Society in Sierra Leone, after long and unwearied labour, finds that she has ultimately lost in great part the fruits accumulated by her own industry. This may be clearly seen when looking into the number of young people brought up in that Society, and the number of promising youths brought up in the college at King Tom's Point in Freetown, most of whom would, to the society's credit, have held prominent positions in its service if a little caution and kindness had been taken and shown by those directing this Society in that colony. But, alas! through gross neglect, these promising youths, especially those composing their agents, were all discouraged and driven out of that Society, and are left entirely to their own way, through the mal-administration of those inexperienced brethren into whose hands the Committee had so confidently entrusted the entire direction of the Society in Sierra Leone. The Wesleyan Missionary Committee seem, at last, to understand the state of things, and what occasioned the losses sustained by the desertion of all their agents, and to have now resolved, not only to extend their field of labour in Africa, but also to raise up as many of these young men as may be found, knowing that they are capable, even in the highest degree, with God's assistance, of effecting the conversion of their countrymen. Would to God the Committee knew the number of promising youths brought up in the Wesleyan College in Freetown, and the unnecessary course pursued in turning them out of the Mission work! These agents could not apply to the Committee for redress, and the Society, in her report, would represent these youths as being very ungodly and undutiful indeed, as brethren on whose testimonies the Committee solely depend, report that all their agents in Sierra Leone are ungodly and undutiful men, and the matter becomes dead and inquired into no further; whilst the contrary is the case. In one of our publications in Freetown we have been able to mention that a Mr. Woode, late agent, who was unreasonably dismissed by one of their ministers, and was afterwards employed in the Customs Department in Freetown, where a liberal salary was allowed him, has been since recalled by this Society to perform catechetical duties, together with a Mr. Samuel Davis, an agent, and Mr. Harding, all of whom are now recommended to the ministry. If those who were set over the affairs of the Society in Sierra Leone had fully known their responsibility to God for the souls of those young men whom they had trained, they would have kept them in the field of labour, and would not have dispensed with their services for frivolous matters. We are also very glad to hear that the Wesleyan Missionary Society in Lagos has recalled and secured the services of the following gentlemen, viz: Messrs. W. B. George, Moses C. Hagan, John B. Deigh, and Samuel B. Taylor; the two former being placed immediately under catechetical duties. All these were students under the Rev. James Jackson Wray, James Robert, and James W. Berry, all European tutors in the Wesleyan Institution, King Tom's Point, in Sierra Leone. There is no doubt that some of these young men could have continued their labours if they had received the slightest encouragement from their superiors; but instead of this, the Committee, it was said, ordered that their services be dispensed with, because a self-supporting system was to be established. We attribute much praise and thanks to the Rev. J. Milum, of Lagos, who has been the instrument in recalling these young men to their original work. Most of them, we learn, are, or were, holding responsible positions and receiving liberal salaries in the Government and other offices in that settlement, yet they hesitated not to return when the offer was made them by that gentleman. This shows that they entertained no desire to leave the Mission service if they had only received encouragement, not thinking that it is any dissatisfaction with their secular position that prompts them to return, but that they set great value upon the work for which they were trained, and cannot rest satisfied till they are grounded in their proper element. Imagine what vast numbers of youths were trained up in the Wesleyan Missionary Society at King Tom's Point. If not more, they are equal, at least, to those trained by the Church Missionary Society in that colony. What of all these promising youths? Can we even point out half-a-dozen useful men amongst them now? Can it be possible that of over a hundred youths trained up by that Society, not one has the desire to minister in the holy Sanctuary of God, but all to be otherwise employed? We answer, No; the fault rests solely on those in the colony who wield the sway of the Society. But the Church Missionary Society seemed to maintain contrary views on this point. For a moment just throw a glance over their field of labour, and you will find that their stations are filled up by young men of their own training. There are ministers, deacons, catechists, and schoolmasters, many of whom are sent into the very heart of Africa to teach and preach the Gospel to their countrymen; and even wherever there be a European missionary, there is also an African agent to be found, as it is utterly impossible for a European to work successfully in heathen lands without assistance being rendered by native agents. Can any of these be pointed out in the Wesleyan Missionary Society? None, but a Mr. Thorpe alone. Messrs. Marke and King are picked-up men. How has this happened? Is it because students of the Church Missionary Society are much better qualified than those of the Wesleyan? Is it because young men from the Wesleyan Missionary Institution are not sufficiently intelligent to minister in these functions? or is it because the Wesleyan Missionary Committee in England has no desire that youths trained at King Tom's Point, at an enormous expense, should be made as useful as those of the Church Missionary Society? We answer, No. It is because those into whose hands the Committee had entrusted the affairs of the Society in Freetown have very greatly erred. They cared but very little for the services, labours, and welfare of their youths, and would not by any means recommend them to the notice of the Committee as deserving promotion, but rather depress them; whilst the Church Missionary Society set great value upon their youths, especially those whom they themselves have trained. We are happy indeed to find that the Wesleyan Missionary Committee at home is now looking into matters from a different point of view, and sending out a man of such a philanthropic character as the Rev. J. Milum is described to be. He, too, seems to view matters in the same light as the Committee now views them; he seems to admire young men of intelligence, values and encourages them in their labours, and manifests great sympathy when necessity requires him to do so. He seems to be aware that Europeans alone, labouring without the assistance of Africans, cannot succeed so well. For if we look at the period when Europeans only were sent out for the Christianization of the Africans, and contrast it with the period since the Bight of Benin was put into the hands of the African Bishop to Christianize, we shall find that the Gospel has more swiftly run its course through the latter. Is it not obvious in this instance that Africans are also one of the very best means to be employed in effecting the conversion of their heathen brethren? Just cast a glance over the Church Missionary stations in the Niger, and you will find that the whole are occupied by Africa's sons. What retards the progress of the Wesleyan Mission, and prevents their occupying stations in this extensive field? Were not a few men—viz., Messrs. Roach, Jackson, and others—sent down that way for the purpose about twenty years ago, perhaps before, if the Church Missionary Society made a movement there? Why...
**15**", 'last_edit_date': '1875-08-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_08_1875#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICA AND THE JUBILEE FUND OF THE WESLEYAN MISSIONARY SOCIETY', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Wesleyan Missionary Society have raised a large Jubilee Fund at Leeds, and other towns. We are glad to see that a prominent place is given to Africa and her children in the contemplated disposal of it. The following is from the monthly organ of the Society: "It was deeply felt by the Committee that the hope for the evangelization of Africa must mainly rest on the employment of a native agency. The difficulties of the African languages form a barrier to the free labour of English missionaries among the African nations, and the climate of large portions of that vast continent is very unfavourable to European health and life. At the same time, on every mission in Western and in Southern Africa there have been found native converts who have been deemed suitable to be employed as teachers among their countrymen. Some of these have been honoured of God with great success. It is desired that means may be provided for the training and employment of a much larger number of native African agents; and that at important centres, hereafter to be selected, schools or institutions should be formed for that purpose, to be commenced and sustained by an appropriation from the Jubilee Fund. In contemplation of the vastness of the field of labour in Africa it will be admitted that a large amount may with propriety be consecrated to this service.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A Sierra Leone Christian', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have been very much struck with a funeral sermon, preached by the Rev. John Trotter, at Basingstoke.* The gentleman whose death occasioned the delivery of this sermon was Mr. James Grafton Hazeley, of Sierra Leone, an African, and a personal friend of Mr. Trotter. It was scarcely possible that such an occasion should be allowed to pass without some notice of the slanderous attacks lately made in England on missionaries in Africa, and on African converts to Christianity. Towards the close of his discourse Mr. Trotter says:—

“As illustrative of the teachings of the text, let me now present you with a very brief account of the life and death of a Sierra Leone Christian. If you expect anything sensational, you will be disappointed, for he was a quiet, respectable, unassuming man, in whom we have a specimen of the quality of West African Christianity. Let this, therefore, be one reply, at least, to the foul charge, that Christianity is the curse of West Africa. It will be seen that he was not connected with our own churches, but was a member of the Wesleyan Mission Church—a church which has been, and still is, of immense good to the West Coast of Africa.”

Mr. Trotter then gives a concise and interesting biography of his deceased friend, who appears from early life to have been a sincere, consistent, and ardent Christian, and finishes with the following remark:—

“Thus lived and thus died a Sierra Leone Christian. He was my own near neighbour in Freetown for some time. We have held sweet counsel together. His image is photographed on the tablet of my memory, never to be erased. When I was sick he visited me, and when I was in trouble he comforted me. Let me die the death of the righteous, and may my last end be like his. And here let me bear my testimony to the native Christians of Sierra Leone. With some few exceptions, greater Christian kindness I never met with from any people. I have seen them live, and I have seen them die. I have seen them in the villages, and in the larger towns. I have seen them taken out of the slave ship naked and down-troden, and I have seen them civilised, educated, and Christianized, and I have no hesitation in saying, that, taking into the account their antecedents, their religion will not lose anything by being contrasted with English Christianity. Any system, therefore, or any man who would rob them of the priceless boon of Christ and Him crucified, deserves to be buried under mountains of reproach. It would be infinite cruelty to dash the cup of salvation from their lips, now, when so many of them have tasted its sweetness; rather let them continue to drink and live for ever.

“In conclusion, enough has been said to prove, that our African friend, Mr. James Grafton Hazeley, was a saint of the Most High God, that his death was safe, happy, and triumphant, and that such a death was precious or right dear in the sight of the Lord.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1865#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.658, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "Why the Wesleyan Missionary Society in Freetown Dispensed with the Great Number of Youths Trained up at King Tom's Point", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'those men recalled? and what was the result of their mission? The Committee in England, as a matter of course, know nothing more than what they are made to understand. Why does the Church Missionary Society succeed so well, and the Wesleyan Society not? It is rather peculiar. It is just for the same reason above set forth that they have not a foot of land on which to establish their mission in that extensive field. It is a sad and shocking reflection. Again, there are Messrs. T. E. Williams, now in Porto Novo, and J. B. Thomas in Lagos. The former laboured over twenty years, and the latter over fifteen years, as schoolmasters. If they were incompetent men, why were they not dispensed with long ago; but if they be competent and qualified men for their work, why not have promoted them long before this time? Does the colour of an African so degrade him as to incapacitate him to be a minister of the Wesleyan Missionary Society? Is there any respect of persons with God in the performance of His services? The Church Missionary Society seems to maintain a contrary opinion. Due deference should be given to Mr. Milum also in this matter, who seems also to entertain a contrary opinion, and, above all, to manifest perfect love for the African race. But for him, who would have brought these useful men to notice? To this godly and affectionate minister only, they owe their truly deserved promotions as reverend gentlemen to-day. We, however, hope that the time is now come in which better encouragements are offered to Wesleyan Missionary agents, and especially to those young men above named, who seem to have at heart a deep interest for the work of God, and come forward willingly, at Mr. Milum's call, for the performance of His holy duties. We trust that liberal salaries is not all that will be granted to them, but also due promotion as occasion may require and permit. By these means the Society will not suffer so much in losing their agents as they have done hitherto. We hope the encouragement intended for them will be such as may instigate their colleagues, now otherwise employed through previous unfortunate neglect, to return and labour likewise, "the harvest being plenty, but labourers few." We cannot close this article without acknowledging our gratitude for the course pursued by our worthy friend the Rev. Mr. Milum, now in Lagos, and attributing much praise and thanks to him. We are glad to hear that he seems to have the interest of Africans so much at heart, and has been thereby able to bring into the mission-field worthy labourers. May he be the means of bringing many more into the fold of Christ, who were long driven away by the errors of his predecessors; and as parents to the Wesleyan Missionary Society in Lagos, may he and his devoted wife, of whose love and kindness we have also heard, long live to be useful in that district, and may they never rest satisfied till they have had the Gospel centred in the very heart of the Lagos district.', 'last_edit_date': '1875-08-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_08_1875#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Joyful Reopening of the Wesleyan Chapel at Abeokuta', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—I write this short letter to inform you that it hath pleased God in His own time to put it into the hearts of the Bashorun and chiefs of the Egba Government to reopen the churches and chapels in Abeokuta, which had been closed since October 13, 1867, in spite of the misunderstandings, which can never be settled, between this and the Lagos Government, so long as the Lagos constables are stationed in the Egba territory. The Wesleyan Chapel was opened for public worship on Sunday, the 9th inst. As had been before mentioned, the European missionaries, who personally parted friends with the Egbas shortly after the riot, are still considered to be out of Abeokuta; although no strong objections have been raised against their coloured agents, who are again sent to preach the Word of God in this "Promised Land." Very many of the Christian converts who left at the same time with the missionaries have returned home, in spite of the warm encouragements of grants of land freely made to them at Ebute Metta by the Administrator of Lagos; thereby giving us a large congregation of about 400 men, women, and children in this small chapel. I must assure you, Mr. Editor, that your letter of April 13, addressed to the Bashorun, chiefs, and people of Abeokuta, has done no end of good toward this result. I am to repeat to you the voice of the people, "May God bless and keep you for Africa, and strengthen you to be always filled with the same zeal for advocating the cause of God, and good to the poor people on the West African Coast." The Rev. M. Grimmer, Minister of the Wesleyan chapel (now at Lagos), has also written a fine letter of encouragement to the converts, beseeching them to unite together, instead of the petty differences and discord known to have been so long existing among them, since Mr. Jas. B. Thomas (their schoolmaster) ruled over the Ogbe chapel. Mr. Grimmer's letter was read to the members a few days previous to the reopening of the chapel, and has done great good in uniting them together. The chapel bell, which had been almost ten months laid aside secretly, without hope, was heard again calling to worship, at the precise hour of ten o'clock Sunday morning; thereby filling with joy the heart of each and every member. Many an aged Christian, with tears rolling down their cheeks, came from far, in the usual slow way (step by step), to feed once more from the words of our Blessed Saviour. May the prayers of that day's service bring down blessings from Heaven. In the absence of a minister, and for fear of being disappointed, the members applied to the Rev. Mr. Allen, a native deacon of the Church Missionary Society here, to preach for them on this occasion. Thus the whole ceremony was ably performed in the usual "Church fashion," giving general satisfaction to everybody. Mr. Allen took his text from Psalm iii. 1—6. The Wesleyan hymns were once more freely echoed in the air of Abeokuta, giving thanks and praises to God the Father, God the Son, and God the Holy Ghost. Amen.—Your obedient servant,', 'last_edit_date': '1868-08-14', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-31', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Great Progress in the Wesleyan Accra Mission: New Chapel Building', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Knowing the interest you take in the evangelization of Western Africa, I had thought that a short account of a most interesting ceremony recently held in connection with the work of the Wesleyan Missionary Society would give you pleasure.

For many years the above society has laboured in Accra in the face of much superstition and indifference; each step of progress has been gained by devoted toil, and the name of the late Rev. H. Wharton will live long in our midst as the patient and indefatigable "seed-sower." The long-expected harvest of the seed he was honoured to sow has now begun, and, instead of a feeble and struggling church of less than 100 members, we rejoice to find in our midst a healthy and vigorous church of 300 members, with a fair number on trial.

This has rendered additional church accommodation necessary, and the ceremony above referred to was the laying of the four corner-stones of a new chapel in Ussher Town, Accra. With a second chapel the machinery of the Mission will be doubled, and we cannot doubt that earnest effort will win still greater success. The service was conducted by the Rev. W. Penrose, assisted by the Rev. J. Plange, native minister; after singing and prayer, a copy of the document deposited within the stone was read, when the minister requested P. Hughes, Esq., Commandant of Accra, to lay the first stone. It is always gratifying to the friends of the Mission when the officers of Her Majesty's Government show their interest in its work. The singing of another hymn followed, when the second stone was laid by F. Ribeiro, Esq., a native merchant of Accra and a most liberal supporter of the Mission. James Bannerman, Esq., solicitor, laid the third stone, and in a few well-chosen words expressed his sympathy with the undertaking. The last stone was laid by J. J. Clayton, Esq., Justice of the Peace, and one of our oldest and most respected English merchants. A liberal collection of 97. showed the practical sympathy upon which the missionaries depend for the completion of the building. The attendance was large, and all passed off most harmoniously.

It is intended to establish a free school in connection with it, so that evangelization and her fair hand-maid, civilization, may journey together. Enclosed is a copy of the document preserved in one of the corner-stones.—Yours truly,', 'last_edit_date': '1876-09-15', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1876#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'CHRISTIAN EDUCATION FOR AND IN AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In answer to an invitation from Samuel Gurney, Esq., to meet Mr. Edward S. Morris, of Philadelphia and Liberia, a meeting was held at Devonshire House, London, April 21st, 1879, when the following resolution was unanimously passed: "That the thanks of this meeting be given to Mr. Morris, for his interesting and encouraging statement on the condition and prospects of Liberia; that we fully agree with him as to the crying necessity for Christian schools in Africa, and earnestly desire that every necessary means may be given him to make his estate (800 acres) in Liberia a nursery of education, industrial as well as literary—especially for the sons of native chiefs, and the future kings of Africa." Mr. Morris was recommended to Samuel Gurney, Esq. by Mr. Welsh, the United States Minister in London, in terms which we feel compelled to quote: "Mr. Morris has thrown an enthusiastic energy into the work he has entered upon, which gives the strongest promise of success. His earnest desire is for the Christian education of the sons of the savage chiefs who border on Liberia. They are to be the future rulers of Africa. This is to be his life-work; and his instruments will be schools for the purpose established in Liberia. In such a cause he cannot fail to have the support of many good people." Mr. Morris has secured an estate of 800 acres in Liberia, where he is about to erect his college, in which he proposes to educate the sons of native kings and chiefs. His admirable plan is to make them at the same time educated men, Christians, and practical coffee planters and general agriculturists. This is surely a work fraught with well-grounded hopes of at present incalculable good to Africa; and as such, Mr. Morris, who seems to us to be peculiarly fitted for it, has our warmest desires and earnest prayers for a full measure of success. Mr. T. A. Denny, of London, has promised 100l. of the 1,000l. required by Mr. Morris, who, in his letter to Joseph Gurney Barclay, Esq., and George Williams, Esq.,—well-known in London business circles—who have accepted the office of Treasurers for the funds which Mr. Morris hopes to collect while in England, says: "When the school-house shall have been built, the teacher engaged and at his post of duty, and the boys in their seats, THEN will I commence to draw on the funds deposited, and placed in your hands as Treasurers."', 'last_edit_date': '1879-04-21', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1879#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.659, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Another Danger than Heathenism for Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Rev. Alex. Crummell, M.A. (Cambridge), writes in a recent letter from Liberia:—

"Our children ought not to be allowed to grow up in ignorance of letters. In absolute ignorance they cannot grow up; for, alas! they are learning all evil things from the heathen. And what will the next generation be? Moreover, we have well nigh at hand another and, I think, as dread a danger impending. The Roman Catholics in a very brief time will be in our midst, with large charities and profuse gifts of money. Ten years have passed since they sent word they intended to occupy Liberia, and now the news comes to us again from Sierra Leone. Already have they seduced some few Liberians, sojourning at Freetown; and two, I hear, have been re-baptized by them. Here they will make an easy prey of our people, for, alas! such a thing as catechising is but seldom known in Liberia. I am speaking of Christians in general in this country. Our religion is too generally one of excitement, and too often marred with

the taint of Antinomianism; and the training of the people has been so very much neglected that there are very few who can give a reason of the faith they profess; very few who have ever read their Bibles. It is these things which fill me with anxiety on the expected approach of the Romanists to our communities. At Sierra Leone they have established themselves at Freetown with power and influence, and are now spreading out to Waterloo, Regent and other old stations. Just so would they do here."', 'last_edit_date': '1868-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1868#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.666, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE CHRISTIAN CIVILIZATION OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Emancipated slaves, or the children of such slaves, now constitute a Christian nation on the coast of Africa, with Christian laws, institutions, and teaching—a state formed after the pattern of that country in which they and their forefathers were in bondage, and where they learned the rudiments of that Christian civilization which they cannot fail to propagate until it embraces and absorbs a great variety of tribes and peoples. And, as if to afford an additional evidence of the correctness of our belief and views, there now comes to us from the United States—from that Virginia which was the chief seat of the suppressed Government of the States which seceded from the Union, but which have now again entered it—intelligence of the approaching departure of a band of voluntary emigrants for Liberia, seemingly the vanguard of a more extensive emigration. In the *Times* of Friday, November 3, the following appeared among the intelligence from the United States: "A large number of negroes living in Virginia have petitioned their former masters for money to help them to go to Liberia. It is said 150 of them will start for that colony on November 1. They say: 'We expect to leave this city on November 1 next, for our fatherland, and leave you all for no reason but the one above mentioned; none of us will carry with us the prejudices and ill-will that might arise from our being held in bondage by you, as your slaves. We know that you have been our best friends, and we feel it now the more, though we are free. You all know the peculiar situation the termination of the late war has left us in; so, therefore, we call upon you to aid us in our enterprise. We know your generous and sympathetic hearts will not let you stand aloof from us in our endeavours to do good for ourselves and people. Some of us are capable of conveying ideas of the mechanical arts; some can unfold to them, in our poor way, the marvellous light of the Gospel, and point them the way to God. We are not going to try to educate the people of Liberia, because from what we can learn they are far our superiors in intelligence, wealth, and learning; but Africa generally. Some of us have a good common education, which we think will be of value to those who have not.'', 'last_edit_date': '1865-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1865#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'GOOD TIDINGS FOR LIBERIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'There is a movement among the Africans in the United States toward Liberia sufficiently marked to have induced the New York Correspondent of the London daily paper, the _Standard_, to give his version of it. We scarcely need say it is not a version very favourable or flattering as regards the Africans of America. For the present, as our space is limited this month, we will only give his facts. He says there is a _strong feeling_ in favour of moving over to Liberia; that "in Charleston alone 2,500 negroes are already enrolled to go to Liberia, and in the State of South Carolina, up to the present time, _thirty thousand_ are enrolled. A grand mass meeting was held in Charleston on the 4th July, at which are reported to have been present between ten and fifteen thousand negroes." "In the churches—generally Methodist and Baptist—which are organized separate from the whites, these movements are generally fostered. All these negro churches have had discourses from their pastors upon this question, and one church is said to have followed its pastor in his zeal to go so far as to have enrolled every one of its members upon the emigrant books."

We purpose alluding further to this great movement in our next. We hope it is not a mere momentary fever, but a settled purpose of emigration, or rather return, to Africa. There has been a general subscription to furnish the funds for three persons to go to Liberia, inspect, and report. We hope they will go back with an account that will bring an influx to the Republic.

We consider that our indefatigable friend, Mr. J. C. Hazeley, from Cape Palmas, who has been lecturing and writing through all the length and breadth of America on the subject of Liberian, has had a great deal to do with this revival of interest for Liberia. The Republic owes him gratitude.', 'last_edit_date': '1877-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1877#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE CHRISTIAN CIVILIZATION OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Among the visible means for the accomplishment of the great work of the Christian civilization of Africa, we have ever pointed to a possible immigration into Africa of considerable numbers of American negroes released from the cruel yoke of slavery. Some people, with more energy than discretion, have from time to time carped at this, and made it a matter for accusation against us that we should hold such a doctrine. According to them, the only civilization for which those children of African blood could have been preparing in slavery, was the civilization of, and civilization in, the United States of America. According to them, the emancipated mass starts forth a species of moral phœnix from the ashes of an immoral servitude—they are admirably fitted for an immediate assimilation of blood with the other citizens of the Republic of European origin or descent—admirably fitted for all the duties of citizenship in the great American Republic; but it can never have been intended by God that the regeneration of Africa should in any way be owing to a preparation of the agents employed, under such a system of slavery as that which has been happily exterminated in the United States. They would have that great mass of people absorbed by the greater mass, by miscegenation or some other similar process—lost as a race by admixture with that mass—and that horrible system of which they were the suffering victims stand out for ever in the history of the past an enormity out of which no good has, no good ever could be evoked.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1865#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Financial contributions from diverse local and international sources, including religious and social organizations, reflect a sustained and structured commitment to educational, social, and infrastructural development in Africa, often influenced by colonial and missionary agendas.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that financial contributions from diverse local and international sources, including religious and social organizations, reflect a sustained and structured commitment to educational, social, and infrastructural development in Africa, often influenced by colonial and missionary agendas. The textbook highlights the significant role of Christian missions, colonial governments, and local African initiatives in spreading education, with missions frequently receiving grants from colonial administrations, thereby demonstrating a structured commitment influenced by these agendas. It also notes the establishment of schools, colleges, and technical institutions funded by religious organizations, contributing to the development of an educated African elite, while acknowledging the inadequacies and uneven distribution of these services, primarily benefiting white settlers and administrators. Similarly, The African Times articles detail various donations and subscriptions from individuals, religious figures, and organizations like the African-Aid Society and the Church Missionary Society, aimed at educational and social initiatives promoting Christianity and civilization. These articles also emphasize the role of European commerce and missionary societies in advancing education and infrastructure, while revealing challenges such as the competition between Christianity and Islam and the criticism of European traders' negative influence. Together, these sources underscore a nuanced portrayal of the contributions, highlighting both the structured commitment and the complexities and mixed motivations behind these efforts.
gha: The paragraphs from the "General History of Africa" textbook provide several details that align with the claim regarding financial contributions from diverse sources for educational, social, and infrastructural development in Africa. The text highlights the role of Christian missions, colonial governments, and local African initiatives in spreading education, with missions often receiving grants from colonial administrations to support their efforts. This reflects a structured commitment influenced by colonial and missionary agendas. Additionally, the text mentions the establishment of schools, colleges, and technical institutions, often funded by religious organizations, which contributed to the development of an educated African elite. The involvement of black missionaries and the influence of pan-Africanist organizations also indicate international contributions to Africa's educational and social development. However, the text also points out the inadequacies and uneven distribution of these services, primarily benefiting white settlers and administrators, which contrasts with the claim of a sustained commitment. Overall, the textbook supports the claim but also highlights the limitations and biases in the distribution of resources during the colonial period.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim of financial contributions from diverse sources reflecting a commitment to development in Africa, influenced by colonial and missionary agendas. The articles mention various donations and subscriptions from individuals, religious figures, and organizations, such as the African-Aid Society, the Wesleyan Missionary Society, and the Church Missionary Society, which are directed towards educational and social initiatives. These contributions are often aimed at promoting Christianity and civilization, as seen in the efforts to establish schools and train native African agents. The articles also highlight the role of European commerce and missionary societies in advancing education and infrastructure, indicating a structured approach to development. However, the articles also reveal challenges, such as the competition between Christianity and Islam, and the criticism of European traders' negative influence, which complicates the narrative of a purely benevolent commitment. This nuanced portrayal aligns with the claim but also underscores the complexities and mixed motivations behind these contributions.
