They did not obliterate all traces of former settlers, but where there had previously been a great variety of clan loyalties, the nineteenth century saw the gradual development of a sense of sharing the same civilization, language, and political organizations, usually in small chief› doms. A feeling of ethnic identity grew out of this shared historical experience, in which increases in population and agricultural productivity, and also encouragement of individual enterprise, played a key role. During the same period, in small high-density areas on the upper Tshikapa and the upper Kasai, there were many young Chokwe who were prepared to leave their villages and the burdensome power of the chiefs and take to the open forest, hunting elephants, setting up hives and collecting the honey and wax. Because of their skill with plants, particularly cassava, which can tolerate poor soils, the women who went with them were able to start growing crops: these women often came from small Lunda settlements along the tributaries of the Luembe, the Tshikapa, etc.
The assimilation of Lunda women into Chokwe society illustrates a phenomenon that was widespread throughout the 'matrilineal belt': descendants of female captives were members not of their mother's clan (this was the privilege of the free-born), but of their father's. There were many of these descendants of slaves everywhere: among the Kongo they were the baæa ba tizo (children of the house), among the Chokwe the ana a tshihunda (children of the village), and among the Pende of Kwilu they even make up the majority of members of rich and powerful clans. 11 Genealogical trees show that the practice of assimilating captives was very common in the nineteenth century. ii. The assimilation of dependents is studied by L. de Sousberghe, 1961.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}]
tat_orig:
[{'id': 534, 'article_title': 'Sherbro', 'full_section_title': 'Sherbro', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1865#article-3', 'issue_date': '23_02_1865', 'content': 'We are indeed, glad to see the progress made in the Sherbro during the past year, thus described by the *Early Dawn*. Sierra Leone is doing something in Africa, and the work of the zealous American missionaries is not fruitless:—

"Peace has prevailed.

"Trade has been prosperous, and the Government is being more fully established and much more highly respected by the people.

"Some good buildings have been erected, roads have been opened, agriculture has received more than usual attention, and there has been general progress in wealth, civilization, and happiness. That the general tone of morals is higher than it has been heretofore, is evident from the fact that marriages are now of common occurrence; formerly they have been rare, even amongst those who claim to be civilized.

"On the whole, the past year has been one of progress for the Sherbro, and the future is full of hope."'}, {'id': 681, 'article_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1865#article-0', 'issue_date': '23_09_1865', 'content': 'In that letter Mr. Rosenbush, who has been eighteen years resident at Sierra Leone, states, as an incontrovertible fact, that missionary efforts have produced very beneficial results—that the most cursory comparison of the people of Sierra Leone, composed in a great measure of Africans liberated from the holds of slave-ships, with the natives of places where the influence of missionaries is not known, will establish this without dispute. We refer our readers again to his letter on this very important point, because we feel that as the past has depended, so the future must in no small degree depend, on this of late most calumniated body of men. Whatever may be the other measures adopted for the advancement of Africa, any relaxation of the efforts of missionaries would be a result deeply to be deplored by every one who is looking and labouring for the day of African regeneration. Mr. Rosenbush's views so intimately coincide with our own as to the means by which "improvement and civilization" may be best advanced in the colony of Sierra Leone, that we may be excused again entering largely upon them at this time. The agricultural improvement of the colony demands the special attention of Government authorities; and when, as in this case, a means is pointed out which only requires a better disposal of the revenues raised in the colony itself, by making them instrumental in obtaining reproductive results from the enforced labour of the criminal portion of the population, instead of that labour being wasted, as at present, no trivial objections or inapplicable theories ought to be allowed to stand in the way of its adoption. There is no wealthy landed proprietary in the colony, themselves acquainted practically with agricultural industry, who might, and would, if they existed, initiate efforts and experiments for developing the resources of the soil. As Christian civilization had to be introduced from Europe, so must the impulse to agricultural industry be introduced from Europe also. The "germ of improvement and civilization" now "lies," as Mr. Rosenbush most truly says, "in Africa, and Africans themselves, aided by European direction, could be the constructors of their own social improvement." But it is idle to expect, and it is cruel to exact, that they should...
**27**'}, {'id': 757, 'article_title': 'The Great Meeting at Abeokuta', 'full_section_title': 'The Great Meeting at Abeokuta', 'last_edit_date': '11-03-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1865#article-14', 'issue_date': '23_12_1865', 'content': "On the 21st of October last, a meeting was held at Sodeke's-street; the bellman first came to my house, to tell me that the Basorun wished me to attend the meeting, to which I went, to see and to hear what they would say. The Basorun himself was present, with many of the war-chiefs and elders also. The first speaker was Akodu, the war-chief of Oba district, who came out and saluted the Basorun, the elders, and the rest of the people. He first thanked the people for the patience they bore since they were driven from Ikorodu by the Governor of Lagos; he then asked the people whether it was not the Governor of Lagos who came to them at Iperu, to ask them to come and take Ikorodu, after they had driven the Ibadans away. The people answered, yes. He asked them again, whether it was not the same Governor of Lagos who came and drove them away, when he knew that Ikorodu was about to be taken. The people answered again as before. He asked them again, if they had heard about the Governor's proceedings by sending many presents to Ogumola, the chief of Ibadan, and the Ijebu Remos, whom they were defending, and where many of their people had died, when the Ibadans determined to destroy them, which they prevented; and how he also sent to the King of Dahomey, begging him to come again to attack Abeokuta this coming dry season, because he was no more a friend to Abeokuta; to which the people replied, yes. He then turned his face towards the Sierra Leone emigrants, and asked them, whether they were not the party that had told them that the white men, i.e. the missionaries, were very good people, they must receive them into the town. The emigrants answered, yes. He asked again, whether they prevented their children from going to church. They answered, no. He asked again, whether they ever prevented the merchants from trading in the town. They said, no. He asked them again, whether they had heard all that the Governor of Lagos is now doing. They answered, yes. He then said that the whole of the Egbas did not know the distinction between white and white; for it seems to them that the missionaries and the Governor of Lagos were both sent to this part of Africa by the Queen of England; he said, now the Governor of Lagos is trying all his best to destroy Abeokuta, and to root out the Word of God from this place; he said that the Governor of Lagos had got some Mohammedans with him there, who were making charms for him, to enable him to carry his purposes through; he said again, that the God of Heaven, whom the Governor of Lagos wanted to deny, and about whom the missionaries here are preaching to their children, and whom they know to be so faithful and true, will surely reward the Governor for his wicked actions. He said again, that they shall have to call all the white men in this town here together, but not to-day: he then took his seat."}, {'id': 3086, 'article_title': 'THE SPAFIELD CHAPEL AT SIERRA LEONE', 'full_section_title': 'THE SPAFIELD CHAPEL AT SIERRA LEONE', 'last_edit_date': '02-28-1876', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1876#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_05_1876', 'content': 'Since the departure of Mr. Trotter in January, 1873, from this settlement, we have received a letter from the Home Mission containing a promise to render us some help; and we are convinced that our not being assisted by the good people in England is owing, not to the want of disposition, but to the absence of such information as may incite the Home Mission to extend their liberality towards us. I believe the representation I have made will have a good effect; already some leaders of the Connexion are making inquiries as to the manner in which the disbursements are made; and there is every reason to believe that their movement will arouse the managers from the indolent repose in which they have so long indulged, to the detriment of the interests of the Spafield Chapel.

I cannot help inquiring in what is the 400l. spent, knowing as I do that every expense in this Connexion is borne by the members. Even the school-room is built by the voluntary contributions of the members. Except the yearly wages of 6l. doled out to the ordained minister, not a farthing of the 400l. is included in the amount spent on the building or for any other purpose.

Considering the grant which is given to the schools in connection with this society by the Government, and the unprogressiveness of this society, the shabbiness of the students' dress, and the menial drudgery to which the students are subjected, one cannot avoid the conclusion that there is a laxity of principle in those who have "kept on this grand religious and educational machinery for less than 400l. a-year." It is the unanimous wish of the majority of the members that they should have the privilege to open free and uncluttered correspondence with the Home Mission; they submit that the practice of transmitting communications through the financial agent is fraught with disadvantage; and in order that the labour already expended may not be lost on Sierra Leone Mission, let this practice be abolished, let the whole machinery be narrowly scrutinized, and then the Sierra Leone Mission will inhale a purer atmosphere, which will give satisfaction to the members, most of whom have every reason to be dissatisfied.—I am, Sir, yours truly,  
A MEMBER.'}, {'id': 3903, 'article_title': 'Letter from North Carolina, United States', 'full_section_title': 'Letter from North Carolina, United States', 'last_edit_date': '10-22-1879', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1879#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_12_1879', 'content': 'Mr. FitzGerald, many a midnight have you paced your room with tears in your eyes, weeping for Africa. You were seen by none but Him who seeth by day as well as by night—Him that never slumbers nor sleeps. You have wondered, you have prayed, you have wept. When, oh, when will the thick darkness disappear? You heard the still, small voice saying, "Fear not; I will overcome the world." Go forward; you have been refreshed, and start anew again. Africa to-day is not the Africa of forty years ago. The Africa of forty years ago was the Africa degraded men turned up their noses against. But when speaking of the Africa of to-day, the civilized and Christian world speak of it as the land of gold and diamonds, of mineral and vegetable resources. Thanks to the great army who have brought my country out thus far, Africa is becoming so important in the eyes of the Christian world that the cobweb of prejudice is being removed. To be knighted, to be decked with laurels, to be honoured, to receive military honours, to receive medals of rare manufacture and taste, to dine at the banquets of England's greatest men, to sit in company with counts and countesses, lords and ladies, dukes and duchesses—yea, to dine with Her Majesty the Queen of Great Britain and the Royal Family, and with the Kings of Europe, you must become an African explorer. Everything now-a-days seems to fall short and become insignificant to the explorers of Africa.

May the time speedily come when railroads and telegraphs will be all through Africa, when West Africa will shake hands with East, North with South! African navies shall then float on the African seas, with the African pennants flying on their topmasts. Then men shall learn to respect her.

"I see, or think I see, a glimmering from afar, A beam of light that shines for Africa, To save her from despair."

Cheer up, Mr. FitzGerald; cheer up; your work is not in vain. Are the works for Africa by the philanthropists and missionaries of England and America in vain? Oh, no; who dare be so blind as not to see the fruits of missionary labours in Sierra Leone and along the whole coast of Africa?

The clock has struck two A.M. My heart and eyes are full. I am pacing up and down my room alone, absorbed in thoughts about my country; all is quiet and still. I must retire, Mr. FitzGerald, and say in conclusion, Africa, Africa, Africa for ever! O Africa, my fatherland! O Africa, my motherland! O Africa, my native land! if I forget thee, O Africa, let my right hand forget her cunning.—I am, my dear Sir, yours very truly,'}, {'id': 6095, 'article_title': 'LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.', 'full_section_title': 'LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_05_1891#article-8', 'issue_date': '04_05_1891', 'content': '[The Editor cannot hold himself responsible for the opinions of his Correspondents.]*

---

**THE C.M.S. AND THE NIGER MISSION.**

*To the Editor of "The African Times,"*

Sir,—In your closing Editorial remarks of January 5, 1891, you seem to blame the authorities of the C.M.S. for their action respecting the Niger Mission; but if you were to be on the spot, and could see the mischief unconverted clergymen are doing, you would not only be sorry for your hasty remarks, but would agree that many of them are a disgrace to the ministry. It is my humble opinion that every station in the Niger Mission should be furnished with white men as in the early days of the Sierra Leone Mission, when our liberated fathers and mothers received such unbounded kindnesses from the hands of the Missionary, and they did their work not with eye-service, or made the Ministry a means to heap up wealth, but they spent even all their living upon our parents as their adopted children. Every Native in West Africa, either in Church or State, owes his position to the goodness of the white people, whilst hardly any Native minister has used his influence to bless another. I pray for the time when every station in the Niger will have European missionaries stationed in them. I am a pure negro myself, and have the good of Africa at heart, but when our country people disgrace the Ministry it reflects on us all, and even the Ministry in Sierra Leone needs equally to be purged of all who enter the Christian Ministry from worldly motives.

*Isaac North Daniel, Native.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The well-being of the British settlement of Sierra Leone has come in for a good deal of attention lately. As must be well known to our readers, this colony was established about a hundred years ago, with the twofold purpose of providing a home, under British protection, for liberated slaves, and at the same time affording a starting-place from which the interior tribes might be reached, and gradually brought under the influence of civilization and Christianity. The improved condition of popular opinion upon the question of the Slave Trade has done away with the need contemplated in the first intention of its founders; but the second and more important part which was to be performed by the founding of this settlement, still remains, at least to a great extent, unfulfilled. In another column will be found some interesting particulars of the present depressed condition of Sierra Leone—a result brought about by the want of purpose manifested by those in charge—and showing the urgent need there is for opening up trade routes between the coast and the interior tribes, who, there is good reason to believe, will be only to ready to enter into commercial relations with the British and native traders on the coast. The Colonial Government—acting, there is reason to believe, on instructions received from the Home authorities—have not been so energetic in this direction as could be looked for, considering the importance of the interests committed to them. It is absolutely necessary for the future well-being and usefulness of the colony that means be taken by which the lawless and uncivilized tribes who surround the settlement should be brought to feel that their mutual jealousies and tribal disputes shall be no longer permitted, by blocking the trade routes through their regions, to interfere with the commerce that would otherwise be carried on between the settlement and the races beyond them. Sir Samuel Rowe's recent action seems to indicate that he is determined to break through precedent where necessary for the well-being of the people under his charge; and though it would appear that he has not met with all the success that was to be hoped for, at least he has shown these lawless tribes that we can and will interfere where necessary for the protection of our interests, and the benefit of the more civilized peoples further away. Some of these races, separated from our colony by this zone of lawlessness, have given evidence more than once of a desire for commerce with our people. Only a short time before the reappointment of Sir Samuel Rowe as Governor, messengers arrived at Freetown from the powerful Chief, named Shahmadoo, of Beri, a place 800 or 900 miles in the interior, beyond Footah. We hear that this Shahmadoo had a large army with him, and had already advanced some distance towards the coast, having expressed his determination, if necessary, to fight the whole way along, and, indeed, that he had already arrived to within a hundred miles of Freetown. He was very desirous that some European officer should be deputed by the authorities to accompany the messengers back with him. His request, however, was not complied with, which is to be regretted, as he professed that his only object was to open up communications between the settlement and his own people, who appear to be a tribe of the Western Soudan. Their country has not been visited by Europeans during the last thirty years, and we are told that they have large stores of gold, ivory, and other commodities, which might be exchanged with profit in Sierra Leone. Taking the account of these people for what it is worth, this, at least, seems to be clear, that there are in the interior races much more highly civilized than those nearer the coast, who will be quite ready directly the opportunity is given them of engaging in commerce with our West Coast settlements, and thus relieving them of the great depression under which they have lately been languishing.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.711, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sierra Leone and Its People', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following interesting account is extracted from one of a series of articles at present appearing in the *Manchester Examiner*, under the heading of "Leaves from a Traveller’s Note-book":—

Sierra Leone, our most flourishing colony on the West African Coast, owes its existence to the measures attending the suppression of the slave trade. There was a settlement there before the British Government commenced its crusade against the traffic in human beings, but the population was very small, and the colony had a precarious existence until it was placed under the control of the African Institution, an organization established for the improvement of the western part of Africa. This body, which had the support of all the great men engaged in the anti-slavery movement in England, directed its efforts to the amelioration of the condition of the freed slaves, and did in its time an immense amount of good. Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone, was made the head-quarters of the association on the coast, and the captured slaves were landed and settled there. An idea of the extent to which this kind of colonization was carried may be gathered from the fact that the total number of slaves emancipated at Sierra Leone between June, 1819, and January, 1833, was 27,697. The exertions of the association were not merely directed to the settlement of the slaves. A system of education was inaugurated, and the settlers were trained in useful arts. The funds of the association were not always well employed, but the general result of their operations is highly satisfactory, and such as to reflect high honour upon the benevolence of the English people. Sierra Leone is now a flourishing colony, and its inhabitants are further advanced on the paths of civilization than, perhaps, any other body of Africans. Education is widely diffused amongst the community, and many of the higher classes have obtained academic distinction in England, and risen to positions of eminence in their own country. In every walk of life, descendants of emancipated slaves are distinguishing themselves, and justifying the confidence of those who believe in the possibility of the civilization of the negro race.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1888#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.726, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FINANCIAL CONDITION OF THE COLONY OF SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It is quite impossible for us to dismiss the very important subject of a deficiency of public revenue at Sierra Leone with the brief notice taken of it in our last. The interesting communications that we have lately inserted, made by persons but too deeply concerned in the Educational department of the colony, on which, with that of religious teaching—the Native Pastorate—the earliest discomforts of the position seem to have fallen, in strict accordance with the old official principles of government in the colony, appeal too strongly to our well-known sympathies and convictions to allow of our doing so. We have received so many letters during the last few months, in which the writers give most saddening pictures of the moral state and condition of the colony, which our personal experience of a too prevalent dishonesty only too fully confirms, that we look upon the curtailment of education and of public religious teaching with the most serious alarm for the future of the colony and for the reputation of Sierra Leoneans everywhere down the Coast. We are quite aware that the old enemies of the African people will point to those conditions of individual mind and practice which our correspondents stigmatize, and of which we complain, and say, "Education and religious teaching, forsooth! behold the fruits of them; we have had too much of them already. Some of the greatest cheats are men who have more than any other a redundancy of Scripture phrases at the tip of their tongue." But they are grossly mistaken. Bad as such men are, they would without doubt have been much worse under the semi-civilizing rule introduced by the British Government, had not the Church and Wesleyan Missionary Societies laboured assiduously to counteract by education and religious teaching the demoralizing effects of example, which has had in time past all the weight of authority and of European intelligence to commend it to African imitation. It is not difficult to account for the prevalent dishonesty without making education and familiarity with Scripture texts responsible for its origin. Not to allude further to example, as already mentioned, the presence of Europeans and the influence of European government have created a wide array of new wants, without providing any other means for obtaining the money necessary to their gratification than Government employment and the pursuits of trade. Handicraftsmen and mechanics there are. The necessities of an advancing civilization have induced these. But where is the organized or individual agricultural enterprise, which would confer wealth on the colony, and give wide-spread, ennobling, and remunerative employment? The production of staples for commerce is still, as in the olden time, a pursuit followed only by the uneducated aborigines in the interior. The result has been the creation of a trading class altogether out of proportion with the demand for European products in the interior, and the quantity of produce offering there for sale, and on which the entire commercial movement of the colony necessarily depends. We have long hoped to see some remedy found for this state of things, without which the healthful moral development, as well as the industrial development, of the colony is impossible. These hopes have been disappointed; and this is perhaps not a time to enter fully into a consideration of the causes that have led to that disappointment. We may say this, however, that sooner or later agricultural and other industrial pursuits connected with the soil must be made honourable in the eyes of the community, and the prevailing stigma of degradation (a curse originating in slave employment in the West India Islands, the United States, the Brazils, Cuba, and other countries into which the victims of an atrocious slave-trade were imported) be removed from it. Already we see the dawn of this happy day in Liberia, which has to depend entirely on its own resources; and we sincerely hope that Sierra Leone will follow suit. With this view we earnestly and emphatically deprecate all money grants by Great Britain to Sierra Leone. Sierra Leone must be made to depend entirely on its own revenues. If those revenues be insufficient for the public service of the colony as at present organized, the work of retrenchment must be at once commenced. A revenue of 80,000l. to 90,000l. a-year, or even a much smaller revenue, ought to suffice for all the legitimate wants of a settlement the population of which is about 40,000, as well as for those of the Sherbro'. There cannot be any valid reason for patching up a rotten state of things by grants from the Imperial Treasury. As old and tried friends of West Africa and its people, we protest against any contributions from the Exchequer of Great Britain to bolster up abuses in Sierra Leone, and thus prolong the existence of a state of things which is working the moral and industrial ruin of the settlement and its people. But that retrenchment, on which we feel thus bound to insist, ought never to have touched the School Department or the Native Pastorate. This is indeed beginning at the wrong end. Educate the people, endeavour to make Christians true and consistent Christians, of the people. This is first need; next after the necessary one of providing a', 'last_edit_date': '1876-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1876#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.702, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Bishop of Sierra Leone on the Education of the West African', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In his book, "Sierra Leone after a Hundred Years" (Seeley & Co.), Bishop Ingham, in reviewing the work which has been accomplished in and around Sierra Leone, observes:—

"It is impossible not to regret that the Church Missionary Society were unable to develop in the schools of the Colony some accurate knowledge of manual trades. The results in aptitude for interior missionary work, in energy, perseverance, and common sense, would have been enormous. ... The other plan (abstract teaching, divorced from material business) has been abundantly tried, and what is the result? Not only does the constant hammering at the brain, of which this raw (negro) youth must now become a victim, produce an unbalanced development, but the precocious memory that will characterise him is a deceptive gauge of progress made, and, like much precociousness elsewhere, the results are disappointing in after life. For this reason, a successfully-passed examination on paper is not the test in Africa that it is in England. ... Can we be surprised that the very last thing he (the negro young man) thinks of is the development of his country or making his father's village better than he found it—and thus his want of accuracy, want of perseverance and skill, and all that goes to make a man master of any situation, remain uncorrected, and put him altogether out of the running. We are convinced that there is a more excellent way, and we regret it has not more generally approved itself to those who have done such good work in other respects in this part of Africa. Other bodies, and notably the Roman Catholics, seem to be far ahead of us in this respect. How far they fail in developing the minds and consciences of the Africans we will not here discuss; but their systems of technical training are thoroughly worthy of imitation."

The Bishop goes on to explain that the work that has been accomplished is by no means to be deprecated—indeed, it is

difficult to imagine how low Sierra Leone must have fallen, mentally and morally, were it not for the mission work carried on in face of such grave difficulties, and upon a soil necessarily so unpromising, since the first occupation of the Colony 107 years ago. But he goes on to illustrate from the physical condition of Sierra Leone; from the manners, customs, and ideas of the Negroes, both lay and clerical; from the suspicion with which the independent States surrounding the Colony regard the morals of its population, the difficulties which face one with such heavy responsibilities as are his.', 'last_edit_date': '1894-07-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_07_1894#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.685, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'PROGRESS OF SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sierra Leone was made in 1808 a depôt for negroes taken out of slave-ships. In 1811 the population was 4,500, of whom more than half were liberated slaves. In 1833 the population had increased to 29,764; and in 1861 to 42,000. The number of liberated slaves brought there between June, 1812, and January, 1833, was 27,167.', 'last_edit_date': '1866-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1866#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.684, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'RAILWAY SCHEMES FOR SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The missionaries in the interior are doing very good work in creating new wants amongst the Natives, but still more can be done by the traders themselves by pushing their trade further afield and studying the requirements and tastes of the Natives. The Upper Mendi, Konno, and Kuranko districts furnish a wide field for commercial enterprise. Manchester woven goods and cotton have scarcely found their way there and where an article is offered which meets a felt want, it is surprising how quickly the Natives acquire it. The eastern portions of the protectorate, which consist of highlands, with a bracing and salubrious climate, are adapted for the cultivation of coffee, ginger, and other valuable products. Another means for the development of the resources of the country would be the settlement of Natives with capital from Sierra Leone and elsewhere, who would carry on such kinds of agriculture. The aborigines live only for the present; they cannot see the force of cultivating plants such as the coffee for the fruits of which they must wait for four or more years. Though slave raiding has ceased, the chiefs still exercise despotic powers, hence there is no security of tenure, and the people are discouraged from making provision for the future; but a closer control by the Government will do away with this feeling of insecurity. Already I have observed in the Sanda Lokko and other districts the cultivation of young kola trees along the approaches to the villages and towns, but this industry might be very much enlarged; and in the hands of enlightened Natives it might be made remunerative. The principal trade routes from beyond the Protectorate are those which enter it across our northern frontier through the French posts at Herimakunna and Wossu. On the eastern frontier between Herimakunna and Kanre Lahun practically no trade passes along them, owing to the deserted condition of the country. From Kanre Lahun a certain amount of trade is done with the interior at the market in the Bandeh country, but this trade is only intermittent. Along the frontier on the Liberian side from Kanre Lahun to the coast of Manoh Salija there is a constant state of warfare, and the border district is a desert. During my recent tour there appeared to be a revival of trade with the interior across our northern frontier, and the number of caravans that came down was unprecedented; but the future prospects of this trade are uncertain, and its continuance cannot be counted on, nor have the products which have come down had an effect in relieving the depressed condition of the market. Considering how very sparsely inhabited are the regions of the Upper Niger it is possible that the trade from that direction is over-rated.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_09_1895#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.709, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE COLONY OF SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'From the report of the Colonial Secretary of Sierra Leone for 1896, which has just been published, it appears that the revenue was £97,109, of which £76,888 was derived from Customs duties, while the expenditure was £116,183—an excess due to certain unforeseen expenses, among them the cost of the Anglo-French Boundary Commission. At the end of the year, however, the total assets of the colony exceeded the liabilities by £19,355; but Sierra Leone contributes nothing to the cost of maintaining the local troops, which last year amounted to £64,421. The total value of the imports last year was £494,688, of which four-fifths came from the United Kingdom. Geneva and rum are the most important articles in the import trade; last year they showed a large decrease, but the increase in other articles, especially cotton goods and hardware, were so great that on the whole year there was an increase of 16 per cent. in imports. The exports amounted to £449,038, a slight decrease on the previous year. This was in the export of African produce, due in great measure to the action of some Native chiefs in the protectorate who were discontented with the new arrangements for levying duties on spirits, and prohibited their people from gathering and selling the produce. Half the total export trade is with the United Kingdom. It has been ascertained during the year that there are large tracts of country in the protectorate in which the valuable rubber-tree, *Kicksia Africana,* abounds. The construction of the railway between Freetown and Songo Town has been commenced, and good progress has been made. A protectorate was proclaimed in August over certain territories adjacent to the colony within the British sphere of influence. The area is about 30,000 square miles, and the population is estimated at from a quarter to half a million. The protectorate is divided for police purposes into five districts; three different kinds of Courts were established—those of the Native chiefs, those in which the chiefs and the District Commissioner sit together, and those of the District Commissioner alone. All civil cases and the lesser criminal ones go to the Native chiefs; the mixed Court tries all graver criminal matters, while the District Commissioner alone tries all cases in which persons who are not Natives are concerned. All capital cases go to the Supreme Court of the Colony, as well as certain specified offences, such as witchcraft, slave-raiding and slave dealing, faction or tribal fights, and the like. The revenue of the protectorate is derived from licenses and a house tax. The staff in each district consists of a District Commissioner, surgeon, and company of frontier police. Prior to the creation of the protectorate, order was maintained by the frontier police, which within the last few years has quelled all inter-tribal warfare and slave-raiding, and reduced the country to peace and security. The effect of the further establishment of British administration and tribunals has been the movement of a number of Natives from the coast into the interior with the purpose of trading, and there is therefore every hope of an increasing development of the natural products of the protectorate in the near future.', 'last_edit_date': '1897-11-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_11_1897#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.69, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Copy of the Report of Col. Ord', 'section_title': '', 'content': "All these people are under chiefs who govern larger or smaller communities, according to their wealth and influence, and with many of them, occupying the coast from the River Pongas on the north, to the River Gallinas on the south, and to a distance of four days' journey up the Sierra Leone river, the Government has established

relations. This has been done by treaties, which stipulate that the slave trade shall be abolished, that perfect freedom of trade shall be allowed in their countries, and their canoes permitted to come to our ports; that British subjects shall be protected, and if they commit offences, shall be sent to Sierra Leone for trial. In return they receive stipends varying from 5l. to 100l., and involving a total cost to the local Government of nearly 1,400l. a-year. It was urged by the Chamber of Commerce that this money was ill bestowed, but this is not established on inquiry. No doubt some of the treaties are with chiefs whose influence has greatly diminished since they were entered into; and, as no provision was made for such a contingency, there may be a few cases out of the whole seventy-nine in which the stipend is paid without an adequate return.

In the majority of instances, however, this is not the case; the treaties are generally faithfully observed, and, where they are broken by the people, it is found that a threat of withdrawing his subsidy has generally the effect of inducing the chief to compel the offenders to make restitution.

It is unquestionable that by means of these treaties the Sierra Leone Government exercises an influence over a large extent of country from which it would otherwise be excluded—an influence which is most useful in securing the safety of its trade and the protection of its people, as well as enabling it to interfere on occasions between the natives themselves, not only greatly to their advantage, but often for the security and peace of the settlement.

The slave-trade, understanding thereby the export of slaves to America, is unknown in Sierra Leone; but as domestic slavery exists in every part of the continent not under British rule, it has constantly happened that the natives, whilst engaged in transporting purchased or kidnapped slaves from one part of the country to another, find they have brought themselves within the reach of British authority, which at once restores their slaves to liberty.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-26', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.707, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "MR. SIBTHORPE'S LETTER", 'section_title': '', 'content': "Although we had no previous knowledge of Mr. Sibthorpe or his labours, which, as now reported by him, entitle him to the warmest praise, we have without hesitation inserted his letter in full, bearing as it does upon a subject that has long seriously and painfully occupied our mind. The necessity of some great development of Sierra Leone mercantile resources has long been evident. The encroachments of the French in the neighbouring rivers greatly hinder that development; and it cannot be thought probable that the aids to Sierra Leone revenue now given by the Sherbro' countries will permanently continue. In Sherbro' everything seems to have been sacrificed to secure a large surplus revenue to augment the income of Sierra Leone. In many admirable communications from Sherbro' we have long since exposed the injustice with which that dependency has been treated. It is a country of great resources, but those resources are crippled by the disadvantages under which merchants and traders have there laboured, owing to the meagre and ill-paid official staff, the want of adequate protection, and the neglect of those improvements for which the duties levied on its trade would provide, and to which it is therefore justly entitled. It is self-evident that in the near future a much larger proportion of the amount annually derived from those duties must be spent in Sherbro'; that the much-needed improvements cannot be longer delayed; that there must be a largely-increased and better-paid staff; more expenditure for sanitary measures and for the supply of adequate public buildings; or that the Sherbro' must have a separate administration, as in the Gambia, when the whole of the revenue levied will have to be expended in the Sherbro' itself. The question of resources of Sierra Leone proper becomes therefore one of yearly increasing importance. With reference to this, we have never ceased to deplore the little attention that has been paid to agriculture, and the seeming absence of all research into the latent wealth of its territory. We were therefore greatly pleased to hear of the efforts making by Mr. Lardner to induce the cultivation of cocoa, coffee, ...", 'last_edit_date': '1879-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1879#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Liverpool and the African Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Tomlinson brought forward a letter from a leading trader at Sierra Leone, urging that in the matter of the construction of railways the claims of Sierra Leone should not be overlooked, and expressing the opinion that in a few years England would reap the benefit of building a railway to develop the resources of the hinterlands of the Colony.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-01-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/06_02_1895#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.711, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'RAILWAY SCHEMES FOR SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'When there is a promise of a settled and peaceful state of affairs it is disappointing that it should not result in a greater flow of trade. There are various causes assigned for the depression in Sierra Leone. I may mention some of these. Stoppage of the slave traffic: A few years ago it was the practice of traders, called Banjuls, from Bathurst, to betake themselves to the riverine towns of the Protectorate, and purchase slaves brought from up-country, and take them back to Bathurst; and the money brought for this purpose was usually spent in Freetown. Again, traders from the Susu country and Futa Yallon used to drive cattle to Freetown, barter them there for trade guns, powder, and Manchester goods, proceed up country—preferably to those parts where slave raiding and tribal wars were going on—purchase the captives taken, and return with them to their own country. All this trade is now stopped, and I do not suppose any right-minded person can regret it when he considers the iniquities of the slave traffic. During my tour last year in the interior I released several parties of slaves consisting of men, women, and children, either shackled with chains or led along tied to one another with halters round their necks. Another cause of the depression has been attributed to the attitude assumed by the domestic slaves, who are not so subservient as formerly to their masters, who find it difficult to get them to gather the produce and send it to the markets. However, I have found that those masters who treat their slaves kindly do not lose them. Hundreds of slaves come every week to Freetown with trade canoes across from Bullom and the adjacent shores, and I have heard no complaints of their deserting their masters. A third cause assigned is the influx of Natives from the interior and the emigration of labourers. It is estimated that 6,000 labourers have proceeded to the Congo since the commencement of the year. This emigration may affect the producing power, but numbers of these labourers return with their wages, which they spend in the Colony; and those who come to Freetown and obtain work there convert their earnings into goods and return with them to their masters. The cessation of the raids and wars which supplied the slave traders, and the entire prohibition of the traffic, must revolutionise the system of trade, and probably accounts for some of the depression that has prevailed, which has been even more felt in French Guinea, as I am informed, than in the Colony of Sierra Leone.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_09_1895#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.697, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Colony of Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': '| Year | United Kingdom | Colonies | Foreign | Total |
|------|----------------|----------|---------|-------|
| 1887 | £247,764       | £1,933   | £58,351 | £308,038 |
| 1888 | 190,529        | 1,211    | 58,407  | 250,147 |
| 1889 | 210,800        | 1,110    | 65,871  | 277,781 |
| 1890 | 295,012        | 1,627    | 93,269  | 389,908 |
| 1891 | 345,031        | 2,145    | 106,202 | 453,378 |

Of the imports in 1891 that entered for home consumption was £298,137, merchandise warehoused amounted to £146,553, and £8,688 worth of goods was transhipped. The increase in the value of importations in 1891 over those of 1890 was £63,470. The principal articles imported were—cotton goods, £139,954; spirits, £27,991; haberdashery, £23,679; tobacco, £22,253. The value of imports from the United Kingdom was thirty-four times that from France and ten times that from Germany.

**Exports.**

| Year | United Kingdom | Colonies | Foreign | Total |
|------|----------------|----------|---------|-------|
| 1887 | £120,188       | £15,695  | £197,634| £333,517 |
| 1888 | 166,569        | 17,651   | 154,823 | 339,043 |
| 1889 | 131,077        | 23,992   | 164,650 | 319,719 |
| 1890 | 147,436        | 21,043   | 180,840 | 349,319 |
| 1891 | 218,294        | 32,177   | 227,185 | 477,656 |

The value of produce exported was £329,751, and of European goods £137,905. The increase in the exports of 1891 over those of 1890 was £128,837, which was more than the total exports to the United Kingdom in 1887. Articles produced or manufactured in and exported from the Colony in 1891 were valued at £6,177, against £5,394 in the previous year. The chief exports were palm kernels £157,457, rubber £77,738, kola nuts £43,004, specie £36,231, palm oil £14,370, gum copal, £9,241, rice £8,291, and hides £7,112. The exports to the United Kingdom in 1891 was four times that to France, five times that to Germany, and twenty-five times that to the United States of America. These figures afford evidence that the trade of the Colony is expanding, a satisfactory feature in a community in which about one-sixth of the resident inhabitants is engaged in trading. Probably the large importations of recent years are not altogether the outcome of increased local consumption, as nearly one-half the imports find their way into the interior countries, and should more properly be classified as transit trade, the few ports in the Colony being mere commercial depots, where are landed the merchandise brought by vessels from different countries, whose manufactures find a market in this part of West Africa. Therefore the stability of the trade of Sierra Leone rests on the pacification of the producing areas which border upon it.

Freetown has become noted as a coaling station, and as it possesses an admirable harbour, a good provision market, and plenty of pure drinking water, it is much frequented by ships, as such supplies cannot be so readily obtained elsewhere on the coast.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1893#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.739, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Natural Products of Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Much interesting and useful information may be gleaned from the Colonial Office report lately issued with reference to Sierra Leone. It has been compiled by Mr. G. F. Scott-Elliott and Miss Catherine A. Raisin, and deals exhaustively with the botany and geology of that Colony. One or two of the matters with which it deals may be noted. Sugar-cane is cultivated, and seems suited to the climate, and the £3,500 worth of sugar imported by the Colony in 1890 may—the authors of the report state—be easily produced on the spot. Arrowroot grows exceedingly well; indeed, that of Sierra Leone is claimed to be the best in the world. But unfortunately the market has been spoilt because the Natives adulterated the flour with cassada and would not clean it properly. African flax or bow-string hemp is extremely common in the district. Its excellent character is well known, but so far the difficulty of preparing it for the market has not been overcome, and it is suggested that the processes of cleaning might be improved by first passing the leaves lengthwise through two horizontal rollers placed close together. Banana fibre is also referred to. As fibre, it can, perhaps, scarcely compete with other substances, but has scarcely yet had a fair practical trial. Usually the old stems are cut into four, lengthwise, the soft heart is taken out, and the pieces, after being left lying two or three days, are passed lengthwise through two horizontal rollers and washed. A tree yields about 4 lbs. of fibre, which is worth from £12 to £20 a ton. Waste stems might be profitably utilised in this way, though a plantation for fibre purposes could scarcely pay. There should be a large export trade in bananas, which sell at about 8d. a bunch. The authors think that with good roads, the supply of rubber from the Colony may be doubled or even quadrupled in amount, while the demand for this most useful article is capable of almost endless expansion. The obstacles to the trade are the constant Native wars prevailing in the interior.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-09-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_09_1893#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.692, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Proposed Light Railway for Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On Tuesday, March 7, Surgeon-Major Lamprey, Army Medical Staff of the Sierra Leone Delimitation Commission, read a paper on this subject before the African section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce. Mr. A. L. Jones occupied the chair, and in introducing the lecturer said the idea was to get the Government to open up the country either by railways or water navigation. The West African colonies were now paying very well, and it was not fair to tax the people without doing something in return.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1893#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.687, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sierra Leone and Its People', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A stroll through the town is very interesting. There are no wheeled vehicles whatever in the place, and the roadways are covered with grass. Excepting in one or two of the principal streets, the houses by the sides of the road stand in gardens full of trees, whose branches stretch over the pathway and afford protection against the rays of the sun. Most people walk, but a few are carried about in a hammock swung from a piece of wood which is borne on the shoulders of four sturdy natives, much in the same way as a palanquin is carried in India. The bearers proceed at a rapid pace, with an easy gliding motion which renders this form of locomotion very comfortable and enjoyable in a climate like that of Sierra Leone, where the thermometer rarely goes much below eighty. Although vehicular traffic is absent, there is no lack of life in the streets of Freetown. The main thoroughfares are crowded with people, and there is plenty of animation and bustle. Fat, jolly-looking negresses, with bright coloured Manchester kerchiefs wound picturesquely round their woolly heads, sit at the street corners presiding over baskets of native produce. Native dandies, attired in what they probably consider the height of fashion, lounge about the principal shops, eyeing the passers-by. There is a cheerful air about all, and every one appears to take life easily. Negroes are proverbially merry-hearted, but I did not know how merry was their disposition until I had been to Sierra Leone, and had an opportunity of seeing them in their own homes. They laugh and joke incessantly, and it is a rare thing to see a sour or unhappy face amongst them. English is the principal language spoken, and most of the shops are for the sale of English goods. One long street is full of shops devoted to the sale of Manchester prints and Birmingham hardware. Amongst the latter I noticed a number of flimsy-looking rifles, which, I imagine, would do more injury to the persons who fired them than to those they were fired at, and a quantity of cheap swords, equally effective in appearance. These articles, I suppose, have a value here, as there is a great demand for them in the interior, and they constitute an important medium of exchange, without which commercial transactions could not be carried through. The names upon the shops are English, and also the notices, which sometimes are of a quaint character; but the retail trade is entirely in the hands of the natives. The export trade consists chiefly of coconuts, benniseed, ginger, ground nuts, and other natural products, and the imports of ale and porter, wine and spirits, and manufactured goods of various kinds.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1888#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.704, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: Missionary activities in Africa were driven by a belief in divine blessing and duty, perceived as acts of mercy and spiritual endeavors aligned with religious convictions.
result: The observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that missionary activities in Africa were driven by a belief in divine blessing and duty, perceived as acts of mercy and spiritual endeavors aligned with religious convictions. The General History of Africa highlights that missionaries felt a divine duty to bring salvation and grace to African peoples, evidenced by their efforts to spread Christianity and establish schools as a means of evangelization. Their humanitarian and philanthropic zeal is noted, alongside their role in preparing the ground for colonialism, which they saw as morally justified. The text also points out the missionaries' negative attitude towards African religion and culture, which they sought to replace with Christianity, indicating their belief in the superiority of their religious convictions. However, it acknowledges that missionary activities were also intertwined with colonial interests and economic opportunities, suggesting a complexity beyond purely spiritual motives. Similarly, The African Times articles emphasize the missionaries' reliance on divine providence and their perception of their work as a spiritual calling, with missions undertaken "in dependence upon God" and seen as a privilege and duty to spread Christianity. The emphasis on prayer, hymns, and religious ceremonies underscores the spiritual nature of their mission, while efforts to combat superstition and promote Christianity as a moral and civilizing force align with the claim of their activities being acts of mercy. Nonetheless, the articles also recognize challenges such as the negative influence of European traders and competition with Islam, complicating the narrative of purely divine-driven missionary work. Together, these sources portray missionary activities as deeply rooted in religious convictions, perceived as a divine duty, yet also influenced by broader socio-political and economic factors.
gha: The paragraphs from the General History of Africa textbook provide several details that support the claim that missionary activities in Africa were driven by a belief in divine blessing and duty, perceived as acts of mercy and spiritual endeavors aligned with religious convictions. The text highlights that missionaries felt a divine duty to bring salvation and grace to African peoples, as evidenced by their efforts to spread Christianity and establish schools as a means of evangelization. The missionaries' humanitarian and philanthropic zeal is noted, as well as their role in preparing the ground for colonialism, which they saw as a morally justified undertaking. The text also mentions the missionaries' negative attitude towards African religion and culture, which they sought to replace with Christianity, further indicating their belief in the superiority of their religious convictions. However, the text also presents a nuanced view by acknowledging that missionary activities were not solely driven by spiritual motives but were also intertwined with colonial interests and economic opportunities. This complexity suggests that while religious convictions played a significant role, they were not the sole driving force behind missionary activities in Africa.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that missionary activities in Africa were driven by a belief in divine blessing and duty, perceived as acts of mercy and spiritual endeavors aligned with religious convictions. The articles frequently emphasize the missionaries' reliance on divine providence and their perception of their work as a spiritual calling. For instance, the Church Missionary Society's resolution to establish a mission near Victoria Nyanza is described as being undertaken "in dependence upon God," with the expectation of divine blessing. Similarly, the articles highlight the missionaries' view of their work as a privilege and a duty to spread Christianity, as seen in the speeches and letters that express gratitude for being instruments in God's plan for redemption. The emphasis on prayer, hymns, and religious ceremonies further underscores the spiritual nature of their mission. Additionally, the articles mention the missionaries' efforts to combat superstition and promote Christianity as a moral and civilizing force, aligning with the claim of their activities being acts of mercy. However, the articles also acknowledge challenges, such as the negative influence of European traders and the competition with Islam, which complicates the narrative of purely divine-driven missionary work. Overall, the articles largely align with the claim, portraying missionary activities as deeply rooted in religious convictions and perceived as a divine duty.
